de.pruefbit.kata

Class OcrDecode

  • java.lang.Object
    • de.pruefbit.kata.OcrDecode

  • public class OcrDecode
extends java.lang.Object
    This is just another Java implementation of the Bank OCR Kata. You can find the kata at the Coding Dojo of Emmanuel Gaillot.

    • Coding Dojo/Kata/BankOCR
    • Emmanuel Gaillot

    I did implement all four user stories.

    Version:
    1.0
    Author:
    Karl-Dieter Zimmer-Bentin, https://github.com/techrabbit58

    • Method Detail

      • decode

        public static java.lang.String decode(java.lang.String[] scanLine)
        scanLine is assumed to be an array of three strings, each consisting of the same number of characters. If there are different length lines, the length of the first line will give the significant length. Shorter strings at second or third position will cause a runtime error. In any case, the length of all strings is assumed to be divisible by 3. Other cases will cause a runtime error. Only the characters blank, underscore and pipe are allowed in the strings. Decode the three strings to a decimal number. Symbols that can not be decoded, will lead to a runtime error.
        Parameters:
        scanLine - an array of strings
        Returns:
        the digits recognized, as a string, in scanned order left to right

      • isAccountNumberValid

        public static boolean isAccountNumberValid(java.lang.String candidate)
        To validate that the decoded account numbers are in fact valid account numbers, a checksum has to be calculated. The algorithm is as follows:

        1 From left to right go through the decode result (i.e.: the account number candidate). 2 Multiply the leftmost digits value by 9, the next by 8 and so on down to the last digit, which can simply be added (i.e. it is only multiplied by 1). 3 Sum all multiplication results up. 4 The account number is valid if divisible by 11, and not valid in any other case.

        Parameters:
        candidate - the account number string under test
        Returns:
        result

      • markErrOrIll

        public static java.lang.String markErrOrIll(java.lang.String candidate)
        If an account number is not valid, the caller might want to know if the decoded result has a bad checksum (ERR), or if there are unrecognizable digits in the raw scan result. In case of unreadable digits, the decoder puts "?" into the result string. If only the checksum is invalid, all digits seem to be recognized, but perhaps one of it might have a "_" or "|" too much or might miss one in only one digit. If there is only one "?" in the decoded scan result, the corresponding digit might also lack one element, or might have one element too much. In both cases, some recovery may be possible. The function shall count the illegal digits "?" in the decoded scan result, and shall return the "?" count. A 0 result than indicates "all digits valid" (in case of wrong this means "ERR"), and a number .gt. 0 means "ILL" for illegal characters.

        This function marks a given candidate decoded digits string as ERR or ILL, depending on checksum result and/or illegal (unreadable) characters in decoded digits string.

        Parameters:
        candidate - is the candidate digits string
        Returns:
        the candidate, with ERR or ILL appended, as appropriate

      • tryRecoverErrOrIll

        public static java.lang.String tryRecoverErrOrIll(java.lang.String[] scanLine,
                                                  java.lang.String actualResult)
        This routine brings the functionality of findAlternatives(), recoverError() and recoverUnreadable much closer together and creates a cohesive ensemble of the functionality.
        Parameters:
        scanLine - the scan line with bad checksum and/or at least one illegal symbol
        actualResult - the currently known decoded digits, may contain the '?' for unreadable or illegal symbols
        Returns:
        the new actualResult. May be a recovered digit string, or the unchanged actualResult, but with a suffix " AMB" or " ILL".
